reviews.title: Would Stay There Again
reviews.text: It starts right at the entrance. A long, coral-colored wall topped with cascading flowers with a warm wooden door in the center greets you. That door opens into a lush garden and then the house with a view out over the large patio (complete with pool). You are drawn out to see the incredible vistas...two waterfalls, untouched rainforest and a view of the Caribbean in the distant. Our first activity was to take a walk down the property to the waterfall/stream with two of the resident dogs as capable guides.

reviews.title: Fabulous Getaway
reviews.text: Casa Flamboyant is a wonderful rain forest B & B getaway. We were able to relax and de-stress completely there. It is located on the South portion of El Yunque near the end of Hwy. 191, and offers wonderful hiking opportunities in the rain forest and along the Cubuy river. You can hike on your own or have the owner, Shirley, arrange for an English-speaking guide who lives close by.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at Casa Flamboyant for 2 days at the beginning of our visit to Puerto Rico back in December. We had a great stay and it was the perfect start to the trip. The house is on the south side of El Yunque and nestled in the hills. We stayed in one of the rooms in the main floor of the house, the Forever and Ever room. The house itself is well kept and the views are just incredible, especially from the heated horizon pool.
reviews.title: Great Start to Our Trip

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We go every year to Casa Flamboyant in order to "recharge our batteries". We have stayed there for at least for a few days every year. The location is excelelent and Shirley is a great host. She always makes our stay memorable. It is a tour of the senses: Be sure to smell the water lily in the front Garden. We love to watch the night sky from Shirley's heated pool. Somehow we see so many stars, way more than we could ever see even on a clear night in New Jersey. Here the fruits are as fresh as one can get them and be sure to fill your lungs with the clean air. Fall asleep with the sounds of the coquis and wake up to sounds of waterfall. A fantastic place to stay in the middle of nature.
reviews.title: This is where you need to stay in Puerto Rico

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: BEAUTIFUL AND MAGICAL!!! We just returned from a 4-day stay at Casa Flamboyant with our friends. They recommended the getaway as they go every year, and we are THRILLED that we took the recommendation!! This B&B is nestled in a mountain top location in the El Yunque rainforest in Puerto Rico. You are literally surrounded by tropical foilage, waterfalls, and fabulous rainbows after the rain. Banana, papaya, mango, lemons and so much more grow wild and we ate the seasonal fruit every morning. The owner, Shirley Mooney, is a wonderful host. The inn is set up perfectly with a large patio and wonderful heated pool. The rooms were all beautiful and unique with private bath and comfortable settings. I highly recommend the Rainbow Room where we stayed. You have a nicely sized room with sitting area, and your own private balcony looking out at the mountain, valley, with a fantastic view of the island of Vieques. Shirley provided a delicious breakfast every morning...pancakes, french toast, eggs, bacon. A different menu daily...and of course fresh fruit. She also booked a lovely dinner at El Bohio down the road....very good and a fun setting...private and nice. She will also arrange for guided rainforest tours and other types of excursions. Shirley has 3 beautiful dogs they were great!! The evenings were magical with the sounds of the Coqui, and the gentle rainfall. All was amazing! Plus we were only a short drive to the beautiful beaches of Fajardo and Humacao. We cannot wait to go back to this magical setting. Thank you Shirley!!!
reviews.title: A treasure in the rainforest

likes.disliked: — driving up the mountain and lack of dining options
